stories.text:
Lately, I close every website that shows me a big, junky, stupid GPDR cookie consent (e.g. https://www.runnersworld.com/), but honestly I don't find many websites that has a reasonably small and well-designed cookie consent (e.g. https://www.rei.com/).

It seems that these pop-ups are designed to annoy users to force them to click on the Accept button right away, and most of them hide the rejection button somewhere, or make it difficult to find.

The reader mode on the browser works well sometimes, but it's not a permanent way to get rid of those pop-ups.

These pop-ups are making it hard to enjoy the Internet, what do you suggest to do to get rid of these pop-ups?

Thank you.
stories.title: Ask HN: GDPR pop-ups are getting so annying, what should we do about it?
The Travelling Telescope brings stars to students (2021)

stories.text:
Hi all, I’ve been working on this Rust project for a while now, and hope someone might find it useful. It’s written as a CLI app, and there’s also a WebAssembly version you can try out at at https://printfn.github.io/fend-website.

It has support for unit conversions, number base conversions, fractions, complex numbers, variables and D&D-style dice. There’s a bunch of examples in the GitHub README, as well as the manual at https://github.com/printfn/fend/wiki.

Please let me know what you think!
stories.title: Show HN: I made an arbitrary-precision unit-aware calculator in Rust

stories.text:
From a developer's perspective what kind of bugs vs features balance should he/she strives for when working on a product?

Do too many features offer better career development over too many bugs?
stories.title: Ask HN: Too many bugs vs. features in a product
